newsitem.title: PERU: Peru's Fujimori sees Sept inflation up 0.3 pct.
newsitem.headline: Peru's Fujimori sees Sept inflation up 0.3 pct.

text.p: Peruvian President Alberto Fujimori predicted inflation in September would be 0.3 percent, bringing the cumulative nine-month price rise to 9.2 percent.
This would compare with 0.4 percent inflation in September 1995, and a 7.8 percent cumulative rate in the first nine months of last year, according to Central Bank figures.

Fujimori, in a speech late Thursday, added that annualized inflation up to September was 11.7 percent. This compares with 10.0 percent annualized inflation up to September 1995, according to the Central Bank.
The government is predicting annual inflation for 1996 of around 12 percent, up from 10.23 percent last year.
Fujimori also announced that employers' obligatory contributions to state housing fund Fonavi would be reduced to seven percent of their workers' salaries from the current level of nine percent.
